body: How do you propose to provide such a _hint_?

Mh, good question. Those solutions are in my mind:

1. Define a JAR MANIFEST key that may contain the hint.
2. Introduce an interface `DefaultEngineImplementationArtifactHint` in `junit-platform-commons` and the `ServiceLoader` facility.
3. Scan all optional dependency entries of the engine API artifact's `pom.xml`... and pick the right one?!

issue.title: [SUREFIRE-1585] Align JUnit Platform versions
issue.body:
# Overview

The internal `JUnitPlatformProviderInfo` should use the JUnit Platform Launcher artifact version matching the one (highest?) the user's classpath hints to.

## Jira

Issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SUREFIRE-1585

body: @sbrannen and my favorite is: **Define a JAR MANIFEST key that may contain the hint.**

issue.title: Split API and Implementation in two Artifacts

repository.name: jqwik
repository.description: Property-Based Testing on the JUnit Platform

issue.body:
## Testing Problem

Dependency surface could be smaller if API and implementation would be split in two.

Disadvantage: You have to specify two dependencies in Gradle/maven. Unless https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/issues/1669 will be realized.

## Problems

`net.jqwik.api.Arbitraries` has many static methods that delegate to implementation classes. Resolving that without using Java's module system (java 9+) is difficult (impossible?).

body:
Why would that be better than specifying an additional testRuntime dependency? Is it just the one line? 

As soon as we get to Java 9+, the module system will make the separation into two jars redundant or does it?

> Why would that be better than specifying an additional testRuntime dependency? Is it just the one line?

True. For Gradle. In Maven 3 there is no such scope as `test runtime`, iirc.

> As soon as we get to Java 9+, the module system will make the separation into two jars redundant or does it?

Why? From a user's point of view, you write `module test { requires org.junit.jupiter.api; }`. Then, at test runtime, a build tool needs to enhance the enhance the module graph with `org.junit.jupiter.engine` -- imho, the `ServiceLoader` mechanism should kick in resolve the coupling between both modules. Due to `engine reads api` and `provides TestEngine with JupiterTestEngine`. That's a blind guess, need to test it.

### Proposal 1
`JUnit-TestEngine-Implementation-Maven-Artifact-ID: junit-jupiter-engine`

Optional group ID: 
`JUnit-TestEngine-Implementation-Maven-Group-ID: org.junit.jupiter`
If missing, assume same group ID as the current (_api_) artifact belongs to.

Optional version: 
`JUnit-TestEngine-Implementation-Maven-Version: 5.3.1`
If missing, assume same version as the current (_api_) artifact reports.

### Proposal 2

`JUnit-TestEngine-Implementation-Maven-Coordinates: [org.junit.jupiter:]junit-jupiter-engine[:5.3.1]`

Both, the group ID and version, are optional. The build tool needs to extrapolate "missing" values from the current (_api_) artifact.

@rfscholte said in the ASF slack #maven channel:

>  Is there only 1 engine for the API? If so, how about if the api gets the dependency for the engine with scope runtime? Yes, this looks like a circular dependency, but the scope should do the proper magic.

Thus, `junit-jupiter-api:N` would declare a runtime dependency on `junit-jupiter-eninge:X`. And `junit-jupiter-engine` (and its transitive dependencies) **won't** appear on the test compile path in Maven.

What about Gradle, @marcphilipp? Does it behave similar?

So, if we introduced a **runtime** dependency from `junit-jupiter-api:5.4.0-SNAPSHOT` on to `junit-jupiter-engine:5.4.0-SNAPSHOT` we have the following picture regarding Maven and Gradle.

### Maven 2 and later

```xml
<dependency>
  <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
  <artifactId>junit-jupiter-api</artifactId>
  <version>5.4.0-SNAPSHOT</version>
  <scope>test</scope>
</dependency>
```

test**Compile** `junit-jupiter-api.jar:...`
test*Runtime* `junit-jupiter-api.jar:junit-jupiter-engine.jar:...`

### Gradle 4.10.2 and earlier

```groovy
testCompile("org.junit.jupiter:junit-jupiter-api:${junitJupiterVersion}")
```

test.**compile** `junit-jupiter-api.jar:junit-jupiter-engine.jar:...`
test.*runtime* `junit-jupiter-api.jar:junit-jupiter-engine.jar:...`


### Gradle 5 and later

```groovy
testCompile("org.junit.jupiter:junit-jupiter-api:${junitJupiterVersion}")
```

test.**compile** `junit-jupiter-api.jar:...`
test.*runtime* `junit-jupiter-api.jar:junit-jupiter-engine.jar:...`

I assume that this `1:1` relation ship is almost 99% the desired one. For rare cases, for when an API should be handled by different engines, they can be added to the test runtime paths as always. For the even rarer cases when the default engine should be excluded, users may `excluded` the default runtime dependency.

rename.to: Introduce runtime dependency from Jupiter API to its Engine

body:
> @rfscholte said in the ASF slack #maven channel:
> 
> > Is there only 1 engine for the API? If so, how about if the api gets the dependency for the engine with scope runtime? Yes, this looks like a circular dependency, but the scope should do the proper magic.

Interesting!

With https://github.com/junit-team/junit5/commit/436342980610f009077bd5d01221f88b75e767c6 the current `5.4.0-SNAPSHOT` (_build in progress_) of the `junit-jupiter-api` includes a runtime dependency to its `junit-jupiter-engine` artifact.

_"Is it secret? It it safe?"_ -- Does it break your build?

Feedback is very welcome.
